    • Multiple imputations by two-level model

Multiple imputations by two-level model

Source: vignettes/Two-level-mi.Rmd
Two-level-mi.Rmd

Set-up and notation

Suppose there are mm studies to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of some test. For the iith study, let

  • TPi\mbox{TP}_i: number of true positives
  • FNi\mbox{FN}_i: number of false negatives
  • FPi\mbox{FP}_i: number of false positives
  • TNi\mbox{TN}_i: number of true negatives

These are the data we wish to collect for each i=1,…,mi=1,\ldots, m. Write Ni=TPi+FNiN_i=\mbox{TP}_i+\mbox{FN}_i, the number of cases; N‾i=FPi+TNi\bar N_i=\mbox{FP}_i + \mbox{TN}_i, the number of non-cases; and ni=Ni+N‾in_i = N_i + \bar N_i, the total sample size.

Let pip_i denote the sensitivity, qiq_i the specificity, and πi\pi_i the prevalence of cases in the iith study. If there is no missing data, we can easily estimate them by p̂i=TPi/Ni\hat p_i=\mbox{TP}_i/N_i, q̂i=TNi/N‾i\hat q_i=\mbox{TN}_i/\bar N_i, and π̂i=Ni/ni\hat\pi_i=N_i/n_i, respectively. We can also feed the entire data (TPi,FNi,FPi,TNi)(\mbox{TP}_i, \mbox{FN}_i, \mbox{FP}_i, \mbox{TN}_i)(i=1,…,m)(i=1,\ldots, m) into any standard software, e.g., mada (Sousa-Pinto 2022), for meta-analysis.

Methods

A motivating example

Consider the scenario where there are no non-cases in some study ii, so FNi\mbox{FN}_i, TNi=\mbox{TN}_i=NA. An example:

library(mtroc)
uts
#>            TP FN FP  TN
#> Ahn        19  0 NA  NA
#> Bock        5  5  2  17
#> Chung       5  0 48 114
#> Cordoba    21  1 NA  NA
#> Espinosa    5  0 NA  NA
#> Haliloglu   3  0  1  73
#> Langer     57 17 NA  NA
#> Liberman    6  0 NA  NA
#> Nishanova  26  4 NA  NA
#> Obenauer    2  2  0  23
#> Oh          9  0 NA  NA
#> Qian       50  1 63  92
#> Reyes      32  1 NA  NA
#> Robbins     4  0 17 101
#> Taskin     47  0 NA  NA
#> Taylor     21  0 NA  NA
#> Yang       21  0 NA  NA
#> Myers      33  0 NA  NA
#> Taron      19  0 NA  NA
#> Son         6  0  6  23
#> Jafari     31  0 NA  NA
#> Wang      110 18 NA  NA

We aim to fill in the missing values of FNi\mbox{FN}_i and TNi\mbox{TN}_i by multiple imputations (MI).

Two-level random-effects models

We can think of the data as generated in two stages. First, with total sample size nin_i, the relative size of NiN_i vs N‾i\bar N_i is determined by prevalence πi\pi_i. Second, given NiN_i and N‾i\bar N_i, the relative size of TPi\mbox{TP}_i vs FNi\mbox{FN}_i, and that of FPi\mbox{FP}_i vs TNi\mbox{TN}_i, are determined by sensitivity pip_i and specificity qiq_i, respectively. This leads us to posit a two-level model for prevalence and for sensitivity-specificity relationship: the first allows us to impute the size of cases or non-cases; the second to impute specificity from sensitivity (or vice versa).

To account for between-study heterogeneity, we add study-specific random effects on the logit scale of each model. Write ${\rm logit}(x)=\log\{x/(1-x)\}$. $$\begin{align}\tag{1} {\rm logit}(\pi_i)&= \alpha_0 + \varepsilon_i\\ {\rm logit}(q_i) &= (\beta_0 + b_{0i}) + (\beta_1 + b_{1i}){\rm logit}(p_i), \end{align}$$ where (α0,β0,β1)(\alpha_0, \beta_0, \beta_1) are fixed effects, εi∼N(0,σπ2)\varepsilon_i\sim N(0, \sigma_\pi^2), $b_i=(b_{0i}, b_{1i})^{\rm T}\sim N(0, \Sigma_b)$, and εi⊥bi\varepsilon_i\perp b_i. In particular, model (1) maximally allows for study-to-study variations in the prevalence and in the (generally negative) correlation between sensitivity and specificity.

References

Sousa-Pinto, Philipp Doebler with contributions from Bernardo. 2022. “Mada: Meta-Analysis of Diagnostic Accuracy.” https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=mada.
